title: 日本航空證實遭電郵詐騙3億8400萬日圓 香港日本警方FBI聯手調查

replies.msg:
日本航空（JAL）今天證實，今年8、9月先後遭歹徒詐騙3億8400萬日圓（約1億176萬元台幣），日航已跨國向不同單位的警方報案。

報導指稱，歹徒假冒出租波音777-300ER給日航的業者，寄電郵通知日航，將原應支付到美國帳戶的租金改匯到香港的銀行帳戶，日航一時不察匯款，直到正港出租業者來信追討租金，才發現被騙，已分別向香港當局和美國聯邦調查局（FBI）報案。（陳怡妏／綜合外電報導）

Japan Airlines Co. fell for a scam that caused it to transfer 380 million yen ($3.36 million) to the bank account of an individual masquerading as a JAL business partner.

As of Dec. 20, the carrier had submitted documents to show it had been defrauded to the Metropolitan Police Department in Tokyo, police in Hong Kong, where the bank that received the remittance from JAL is located, and the FBI.

The swindle was triggered by a bogus e-mail demanding JAL cough up fees for a Boeing 777 aircraft that was leased by a financial company in the United States.

According to JAL, it received an e-mail on Sept. 25 from an individual claiming to work for the financial company that deals with JAL, informing the company of a change in bank account details to one in Hong Kong.

The message appeared genuine as it carried the same e-mail details as the one used by the actual employee of the financial company. JAL transferred 360 million yen to the Hong Kong bank on Sept. 29.

It realized something was amiss in October when it received an authentic notice of overdue payment for the lease fees from the financial company.

The money had already been withdrawn from the account in Hong Kong.

JAL’s U.S.-based cargo office also disclosed that it was defrauded of a total of 24 million yen in August and September due to online scamming employing similar tactics.
